newsitem.title: UK: Caymans law tightens screws on money launderers.
newsitem.headline: Caymans law tightens screws on money launderers.

text.p: The proceeds of serious crime being laundered in the Cayman Islands now risk being seized by the islands' authorities under the terms of a new law, the Caribbean island group said on Monday.

"This legislation makes it clear that the Cayman Islands is not a place for those who wish to hide illicit proceeds," said Richard Coles, the islands' attorney general, in a statement released in London.
"It will also reassure those legitimate users of the financial services in the Cayman Islands that their business will not be tainted by any illicit proceeds," he added.
The Cayman Islands, which passed the law late on Friday, is the first centre in the Caribbean to introduce such legislation. It is based on British law and the UK welcomed the move.

"This decision marks an important step in the Caymans' fight against international money laundering and will help to ensure that the Islands are not used to hide or launder illicit proceeds," a British foreign office spokesman said.
The law makes it a criminal offence if a provider of financial services fails to report any suspicions that a client may be involved with or be benefiting from crime.

It also allows applications to be made to the courts for an order restraining and eventually confiscating criminal proceeds, whether in the form of property or the contents of a bank account, pending prosecution.
Confiscation orders made in designated nations may now also be registered in the islands and enforced by its grand court.
Britain is pressing other dependent territories to follow the islands' example as soon as possible, the statement added. --Caroline Brothers, London Newsroom +44 171 542 2734
